title: 111_s3810
content: The Act may be cited as the "Gulf Security and Iran Sanctions Enforcement Act" and includes a restriction on participation in offshore oil and gas leasing. The "Gulf Security and Iran Sanctions Enforcement Act" mandates that leases for drilling on the Outer Continental Shelf require annual certification from lessees to confirm compliance with Iran sanctions, with lease cancellation as a consequence of non-compliance. The "Gulf Security and Iran Sanctions Enforcement Act" requires annual certification from lessees for Outer Continental Shelf drilling leases to confirm compliance with Iran sanctions. The Secretary of the Interior can cancel the lease if the certification is false or not provided. The Secretary of the Interior must include a disclosure requirement in each lease for drilling on the Outer Continental Shelf, requiring lessees to disclose any involvement in energy-related ventures outside Iran involving blocked individuals. Any person whose property and interests are blocked under Executive Orders 13224 and 13382 related to terrorism and weapons of mass destruction proliferation. The Secretary can cancel a lease if a person fails to disclose involvement with entities related to terrorism or weapons of mass destruction proliferation. The Secretary can cancel a lease if a person fails to disclose or provides false information, with the option for waiver on a case-by-case basis. The Secretary can cancel a lease for failure to disclose or providing false information, with waivers granted on a case-by-case basis if in the national interest. The Secretary must report waivers granted and promptly report any lease cancellations to congressional committees. The Secretary must promptly report lease cancellations to congressional committees, providing reasons for the cancellation. "Appropriate congressional committees" refer to specific committees in the House of Representatives and Senate. The term "person" is defined in section 14(14) of the Iran Sanctions Act of 1996. SEC. 3. SUNSET. The Act will end 30 days after the President certifies to Congress that Iran has permanently stopped supporting international terrorism and no longer meets the criteria for being labeled a state sponsor of terrorism. The Arms Export Control Act prohibits the pursuit, acquisition, and development of nuclear, biological, and chemical weapons and missiles if it poses no significant threat to US national security or allies.
